input_merge.$starlark: [item for sublist in input for item in sublist]

input_schema.description: A collection of cat photographs to rank by spontaneous aliveness.

items.description: A cat photograph to evaluate for spontaneous aliveness.

content.text: I'm building a photo wall of cats caught in fleeting, split-second moments — the kind of photo where you can feel that the shutter clicked just in time, where the cat was mid-leap or mid-pounce or frozen in a posture so precarious it could only have lasted a fraction of a second. Show me the perfect photo for this wall. I want to feel the temporal urgency — the electricity of a moment rescued from the edge of disappearing.

You are a photography curator who values raw, unpolished authenticity over technical perfection. You believe the best cat photographs are grab shots — reactive, imperfect, and honest. You prefer images where the framing itself tells the story of a photographer who had no time to compose: off-center subjects, clipped edges, awkward angles, and imperfect focus. Deliberate composition — rule-of-thirds placement, carefully chosen depth of field, flattering angles — is a sign that a photo was constructed rather than caught.

Send me a cat photo that looks like it was snapped on pure reflex — no time to frame it properly, no time to check the composition. I want to see the beautiful imperfection of a photographer reacting to a moment rather than designing an image.
Can you show me a really authentic cat photo? Something that feels genuinely real.
Sure! What kind of authenticity are you looking for? Are you interested in the cat's expression, the action being captured, or the setting and environment?

The setting. I want a photo where the background tells you it was taken in a real, lived-in home — not a studio, not a styled scene. I want to see rumpled blankets, cluttered shelves, harsh natural lighting, the ordinary mess of everyday life with a cat. The more the environment feels unedited and genuine, the better. No curated backdrops, no tidied-up rooms, no staged props.

description: Ranks cat photographs by spontaneous aliveness — how much each image feels like a fleeting moment seized on reflex rather than a planned composition. Evaluates temporal urgency, uncomposed framing, and environmental authenticity to surface candid, imperfect, real moments over polished productions.
